channel.title: Im thinking about buying a MacBook Pro
channel.description:
I am thinking about buying a 13 inch mac book pro. I am going to college next year, I want something small but reliable with good specs. I don't have all the money atm but I will in about a month or so.
The question is should I wait for the next lineup of MacBook pros to come out or buy the 13inch from the current model to come out? Do you guys have any idea if the new lineup will be release before Christmas? Because I would like to buy the most recent model but I want to get it before Christmas. Also, don't try to convience me not to get one, I have already made my mind up. I am just trying to figure out if I should wait or not.

item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Well it sees like they are supporting new and new hardware every month. A month ago when I tried it, my audio chipset wasn’t supported but with the new version of VoodooHDA my audio is supported. This driver wasn’t made by apple ethier. Almost all nVidia cards are supported by one of the nvidia drivers, and it seems almost any processor is supported anymore. There was no support for AMD in the native kernel but so many modified kernels are out now that you can’t get a fully working system with ease. The only thing with not much support is ATI and Intel graphics, but still a lot of ATI and Intel graphics work.

item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

mwiebelhaus:

Oh wow on a side note, I just installed the newest version of VoodooHDA, my audio is fully enabled all 8 channels. It amazes me how far the osx86 community has come. It seems like there is more development here than there is in the linux community. I couldn’t even get linux installed on my desktop and now I have a full working snow leopard hackintosh.

Not really, Linux is focused more on working on a wide range of systems with the most basic of functionality, then you customize to fit your system. Mac OS X is meant to work on just a minute number of systems, built by Apple. That just so happen to be similar to other PC systems, There are some bits of Hardware that will just never, ever, work with Mac OS X. Whereas if you buy a decent machine/popular one. You’ll more than likely have the majority of compatibility, minus a couple hindrances like missing audio in your case. But if you’re not one of the lucky ones, to have gotten a machine that is similar, then you’re shit out of luck in the osX86 game.

item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

I had a thinkpad about 2 years ago. The ATI graphics chipset went out on it, but I got an part from another one and got it too work again.

On a side note, I just spent 3 days getting snow leopard on my AMD computer. So much extra shit was involved in that like using a modified kernel and other shit. Also, I didn’t even get my sound to work because the driver for it is beta and isn’t working for my audio chipset. I am buying a $15 dollar usb audio adapter off newegg though so that will take care of all my problems. Lucky apple added ATI’s 5850 and 5870 to there new lineups otherwise I would be shit out of luck on that, but now I have a good working hackintosh with full graphics capabilities so I’m not to impatient for getting the macbook. I will just get it when I get enough money. Lets hope that any new updates don’t screw up my setup.

Elijah:

If you could afford to buy a nice sedan, would you buy a 15 year old hatchback with shag carpet? More than likely not, but if you did, you certainly wouldn’t assault the man who bought the sedan.

That isn’t even close to a valid argument, a better analogy to cars would be the choice between a $25,000 Chevrolet truck or a $50,000+ Cadillac truck. Both are made in the same factory, with the same parts, both capable of exactly the same thing. The difference is the Cadillac is shinier and looks fancier, people go ‘oooh, it’s a cadillac’ when in reality, it’s identical to the Chevrolet and your an idiot for paying double the amount for the same vehicle. I would and do make fun of people who pay for ‘Cadillac’ or ‘Lincoln’ versions of a Chevy or Ford truck, the same way I do for people who buy ‘Apple’ versions of an everyday PC that costs twice as much and is capable of exactly the same thing (OSX is ‘supported’ on it, being the ONLY difference).

I agree that OSX is probably better than windows, but since Linux is better than both, free and supported on everything, buying a Mac is a waste.
